For 50 years virtually all consumer electronic devices used vacuum tubes.", "dateLastCrawled": "2018-04-09T19:57:00.0000000Z", "richCaption": {"_type": "StructuredValue\/SectionData", "sections": [{"_type": "StructuredValue\/SimpleSection", "name": "Overview", "siteName": "en.wikipedia.org", "description": "An amplifier, electronic amplifier or amp is an electronic device that can increase the power of a signal. An amplifier uses electric power from a power supply to increase the amplitude of a signal. The amount of amplification provided by an amplifier is measured by its gain: the ratio of output voltage, current, or power to input. An amplifier is a circuit that has a power gain greater than one. Vacuum tubes were used in almost all amplifiers until the 1960s–1970s when the transistor, invented in 1947, replaced them. Today, most amplifiers use transistors, but vacuum tubes continue to be used in some applications. De Forest's prototype audio amplifier of 1914. The Audion vacuum tube had a voltage gain of about 5, providing a ..."}, {"_type": "StructuredValue\/SimpleSection", "name": "Properties", "siteName": "en.wikipedia.org", "description": "Amplifier properties are given by parameters that include: 1. Gain, the ratio between the magnitude of output and input signals 2. Bandwidth, the width of the useful frequency range 3. Efficiency, the ratio between the power of the output and total power consumption 4. Linearity, the extent to which the proportion between input and output amplitude is the same for high amplitude and low amplitude input 5. Noise, a measure of undesired noise mixed into the output 6. Output dynamic range, the rati"}, {"_type": "StructuredValue\/SimpleSection", "name": "Negative feedback", "siteName": "en.wikipedia.org", "description": "Negative feedback feeds the difference of the input and part of the output back to the input in a way that cancels out part of the input. The main effect is to reduce the overall gain of the system. However, the unwanted signals introduced by the amplifier are also fed back. Since they are not part of the original input, they are added to the input in opposite phase, subtracting them from the input. In this way, negative feedback acts as a technique to reduce errors. Large amounts of negative fe"}, {"_type": "StructuredValue\/ListSection", "name": "Categories", "siteName": "en.wikipedia.org", "listData": [{"listItems": [{"_type": "Properties\/Link", "text": "Active devices", "url": "https:\/\/en.wikipedia.org\/wiki\/Amplifier#Active_devices"}, {"text": "All amplifiers include some form of active device: this is the device that does the actual amplification. The active device can be a vacuum tube, discrete solid state component, such as a single transistor, or part of an integrated circuit, as in an op-amp. Transistor amplifiers"}]}, {"listItems": [{"_type": "Properties\/Link", "text": "Power amplifiers", "url": "https:\/\/en.wikipedia.org\/wiki\/Amplifier#Power_amplifiers"}, {"text": "A power amplifier is an amplifier designed primarily to increase the power available to a load. Op amps have become very widely used as standardized \"gain blocks\" in circuits due to their versatility; their gain, bandwidth and other characteristics can be c"}]}, {"listItems": [{"_type": "Properties\/Link", "text": "Distributed amplifiers", "url": "https:\/\/en.wikipedia.org\/wiki\/Amplifier#Distributed_amplifiers"}, {"text": "These use balanced transmission lines to separate individual single stage amplifiers, the outputs of which are summed by the same transmission line.
